body: Just out of curiosity and/or ignorance: Why a separate package?

Folks that want/need a signed package are in the minority. I'd rather not
punish everyone else with it.

On Friday, September 6, 2013, David A. Sjøen wrote:

> Just out of curiosity and/or ignorance: Why a separate package?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/373#issuecomment-23931646
> .
But in what way is a signed DLL a burden?

@dabide I don't have direct experience, but the "cons" listed in this stackoverflow answer might address your question. http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5583416/pros-cons-of-strong-named-signed-assemblies#answer-8355937
Is the strong named NuGet package available now?

Yep! 3.1 and later.

On Thu, Jan 9, 2014 at 4:05 AM, David A. Sjøen notifications@github.comwrote:

> Is the strong named NuGet package available now?
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/AutoMapper/AutoMapper/issues/373#issuecomment-31917020
> .

So this unfortunately this is a massive breaking change. If you are going to change the assembly manifest this should be on a major version. Sure, if people rebuild their projects there shouldn't be an issue but for projects like CMS's that use Automapper, they cannot ship with the new version because all plugins built for it will no longer work. This should have been a version 4.0 change. We use Automapper in Umbraco but this means we won't be able to upgrade to 3.1 + until we release a new major version. ... and anyone that decides they want to do a Update-Package AutoMapper will unfortunately get upgraded to a DLL that will break their site since the assembly manifest is different and binding redirects won't work because of the public key change.
Yeah if I could undo that SN removal I would have (now a mistake over 2 years old). Sigh.

haha... i just noticed this date, guess it goes to show we haven't shipped with an upgraded version for a while ;)
Some complaints are only starting to come through now for some reason. Not much we can do though for now!

issue.title: Signed assembly in NuGet

repository.name: Markdown
repository.description: Open source C# implementation of Markdown processor, as featured on Stack Overflow.

issue.body:
Would you mind signing the assembly on NuGet? I'm trying to create a Windows Preview Pane handler, which requires my assembly to be signed.

_If I get it up and running, I'll open-source it too of course._

body: If you hook into the `AppDomain.CurrentDomain.AssemblyResolve += CurrentDomain_AssemblyResolve` event and remove the publickey from the `ResolveEventArgs.Name` and pass that again in `Assembly.Load("string with publickey removed")` and return that assembly. The appdomain will load the dll with or without a SN token / publickey token
Wow! Will definitely check that out, thanks!
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
